results.title: Zoo
results.creator_credit: Firebird Films, Arthur Cantrill and Corinne Cantrill
results.brief_description: David spends a happy day at the zoo looking at and feeding all the animals. When he returns home, he makes a zoo of his own. The animals come to life and the monkeys imprison the keeper and begin to release the other animals. Disaster threatens but Elsie the elephant comes to the rescue. Cast: Aaron Judah. Narration: Aaron Judah. Music: Alan Lane.

results.title: Zonbi the doll
results.creator_credit: Cam Panlock and Multimedia Design, Faculty of Design, Swinburne University of Technology
results.brief_description: This dark 2D animation features a battered little doll in a gloomy prison. When the lid to his box is opened, what happens to Zonbi? WARNING: Some scenes may disturb younger viewers

results.title: Zonation
results.creator_credit: Sydney Scientific Film Society and H Scales
results.brief_description: A group of university students study the zonation pattern of animals and plants on a marine rock platform, and the various physical and biological factors contributing to their distribution. At the highest tide level are blue periwinkles; then the barnacle zone, the worm zone and at low tide level, the cunjevoizone and then kelps. The ways in which various creatures protect themselves against dessication from sun and wind and against being washed off the rocks are shown.

results.title: Zoetrope to Cinemascope
results.brief_description: Not only did Alex Stitt create the first 3D animated feature film with Abra Cadabra (1983) and animate some of Australia’s most iconic commercials, including ‘Life. Be in it’, he also taught kids through play with books like this one.

constellations_primary.name: Learning through play
constellations_primary.description: Alexander Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead’s Zoetrope to Cinemascope educated children about the moving image through posters, cut-outs, puzzles and games, but moving image works have also been used to educate and entertain kids about all aspects of life.

results.description: Not only did Alex Stitt create the first 3D animated feature film with Abra Cadabra (1983) and animate some of Australia’s most iconic commercials, including ‘Life. Be in it’, he also taught kids through play. In 1971, Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead established the Jigsaw Factory in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond. The space was designed for children to have ‘fun in learning’, and the company produced a range of posters, cut-outs, educational toys, puzzles, games and books like this one, Zoetrope to cinemascope, which taught children about the relationship between optical toys and cinema.
description_for_label: Not only did Alex Stitt create the first 3D animated feature film with Abra Cadabra (1983) and animate some of Australia’s most iconic commercials, including ‘Life. Be in it’, he also taught kids through play. In 1971, Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead established the Jigsaw Factory in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond. The space was designed for children to have ‘fun in learning’, and the company produced a range of posters, cut-outs, educational toys, puzzles, games and books like this one, Zoetrope to cinemascope, which taught children about the relationship between optical toys and cinema.

results.title: Zoetrope and praxinoscope
results.brief_description: In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version, the zoetrope, which used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits.

constellations_primary.name: Optical toys, Totoro and terrors
constellations_primary.description: Victorian-era optical toys have inspired the biggest animation studios and the scariest horror films.

results.description:
In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version of the optical illusion. The Daedalum, or ‘wheel of the Devil’, used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits. When rotated it created the illusion of motion, and it became known as the zoetrope.

Over 40 years later, in 1877, French showman and lantern painter Charles-Émile Reynaud developed the praxinoscope, replacing the narrow viewing slots in Horner’s design with an inner circle of mirrors that more brightly reflected the pictures and let more than one person view the gliding images.
description_for_label:
In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version of the optical illusion. The Daedalum, or ‘wheel of the Devil’, used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits. When rotated it created the illusion of motion, and it became known as the zoetrope.

Over 40 years later, in 1877, French showman and lantern painter Charles-Émile Reynaud developed the praxinoscope, replacing the narrow viewing slots in Horner’s design with an inner circle of mirrors that more brightly reflected the pictures and let more than one person view the gliding images.

group_works.title: Large green zoetrope with metal base

results.title: Zoetrope
results.brief_description: Animation device called Zoetrope and assorted animation strips. Body of Zoetrope is a cylinder formation closed on bottom and open at top with a series of slits around top rim and painted green. Wood spindle joins cylinder to metal tiered stand. Zoetrope has five various themed printed paper animation strips depicting illustrations of a sequence of drawings showing motion. Animation strips are either black and white or mono coloured with an animation on both sides.

results.title: Zlateh the Goat
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Winter is late so for Reuven the furrier it is a bad year. After long hesitation he decides to sell Zlateh the goat. However, the pet goat is spared from the butcher’s knife when she saves her young master from a snowstorm.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel and Gene Deitch
